channel.title: Pannai Guide on PPG
channel.description: Recent content in Pannai Guide on PPG

item.title: Why Pannai?
item.description:
From Guessing to Knowing: A Farmer’s Journey#

Two Farmers, Two Approaches, Two Very Different Outcomes#

Meet Ramu and Selvam — two neighboring farmers in Tamil Nadu, both growing tomatoes on similar 2-acre plots. Same soil, same weather, same market. But at the end of the year, their stories are very different.

Ramu’s Story (Without Tracking)#

Ramu has been farming for 15 years. He’s experienced, hardworking, and knows his land well. Like most farmers, he keeps everything in his head.

item.title: Income
item.description:
Income Action#

Record all revenue and sales from your farming activities.

Purpose#

Track money earned from selling crops, livestock products, milk, eggs, or animals.

Key Features#

  • Record sale amounts and dates
  • Track buyer information
  • Link sales to contacts for transaction history
  • Link inventory items to track what was sold
  • Monitor quantities sold
  • Calculate total earnings per module

Available In#

  • Crops
  • Livestock

Inventory Integration#

When recording income, you can link inventory items (Yield category) to track exactly what was sold and automatically update stock levels.

item.title: Seasons
item.description:
Seasons#

Seasons help you organize crop activities by growth cycle. Each season represents one complete crop cycle from preparation to sale, allowing you to track performance and compare results across different periods.

Why Use Seasons?#

  • Organize activities - Group expenses, income, yields, and tasks by crop cycle
  • Compare performance - Analyze profitability across different seasons
  • Track history - Maintain complete records for each growing period
  • Better reporting - Generate season-specific reports

Season Behavior by Crop Type#

Annual Crops#

Annual crops complete their lifecycle in one season. Each new planting should be created as a new crop entry.

item.title: Expenses
item.description:
Expenses Action#

Track all costs and expenditures related to your farming activities. Expense types are intelligently designed for each module to match common farming activities.

Purpose#

Monitor spending on inputs, labor, equipment, maintenance, and other operational costs across all your farm modules.

Key Features#

  • Module-specific expense types - Relevant categories for each module
  • Payment tracking - Record payment method and status
  • Vendor linking - Connect expenses to contacts for purchase history
  • Machine linking - Track which machines were used for the activity
  • Inventory linking - Deduct consumables automatically when recording expenses
  • Cost analysis - Calculate total costs per module, crop, or livestock

Expense Types by Module#

Farm Expenses#

General farm-level costs not tied to specific crops or livestock.

item.title: Fields
item.description:
Fields Module#

Manage your agricultural fields and track their usage history. Associate fields with crops, maintain crop rotation records, and store field-specific activities.

Key Features#

Field Registration#

Register all your fields with details like area, location, and soil type.

Crop Association#

Associate fields with any new crop. Fields can be linked to track which areas are being cultivated for each crop.

Crop History#

View the complete history of crops grown on each field. This helps ensure proper crop rotation and plan future plantings.

item.title: Livestock
item.description:
Livestock Module#

Manage your livestock including cattle, poultry, goats, sheep, and pigs. Track animals by purpose, monitor yields, and optionally track dairy cattle individually for detailed production records.

Key Features#

Animal Types#

Support for Cattle, Poultry, Goat, Sheep, Pig, and Others. Each type has specific “Raised For” options.

Purpose Tracking#

Specify why you’re raising the livestock: Dairy, Meat, Breeding, Egg production, or Others.

Individual Tracking#

For dairy cattle, enable individual tracking to monitor each animal separately with detailed yield and health records.

item.title: Tasks
item.description:
Tasks Action#

Schedule and manage farming activities, set reminders, and track completion of farm work.

Purpose#

Plan and track activities like irrigation, spraying, harvesting, vaccinations, and maintenance. Stay organized with due dates, priorities, and status tracking.

Key Features#

  • Due dates - Set deadlines for activities
  • Priority levels - Mark tasks as high, medium, or low priority
  • Status tracking - Track pending, in-progress, and completed tasks
  • Reminders - Get notified about upcoming activities
  • Module linking - Tasks are linked to specific crops, livestock, fields, etc.

Available In#

Module Example Tasks
Farm Property maintenance, team meetings, license renewals
Crops Irrigation, spraying, weeding, fertilizing, harvesting
Fields Land preparation, boundary repairs, soil testing
Livestock Vaccination, health checkups, breeding, deworming
Machines Oil change, servicing, tire replacement, repairs
Inventory Stock check, reorder supplies, expiry monitoring

Task Status#

Status Description
Pending Task is scheduled but not yet started
In Progress Work has begun on the task
Completed Task has been finished

Priority Levels#

Priority Use For
High Urgent tasks that need immediate attention (e.g., pest outbreak, sick animal)
Medium Important tasks with flexible timing (e.g., scheduled spraying, routine checkup)
Low Tasks that can be done when time permits (e.g., equipment cleaning, record updates)

Common Task Examples#

Crop Tasks#

  • Schedule irrigation every 3 days
  • Spray pesticide next Monday
  • Harvest tomatoes by end of week
  • Apply fertilizer after rain

Livestock Tasks#

  • Vaccinate cattle on 15th
  • Call vet for health checkup
  • Order feed before stock runs out
  • Clean shed every Saturday

Machine Tasks#

  • Service tractor after 100 hours
  • Change oil next month
  • Replace worn tires
  • Check hydraulic fluid levels

Tips#

  • Create tasks for recurring activities like weekly spraying or monthly maintenance
  • Set priorities to focus on urgent farming activities first
  • Review pending tasks daily to stay on top of farm work
  • Link tasks to the correct module for organized tracking
  • Use task descriptions to note specific instructions or quantities

Best Practices#

  • Plan tasks at the beginning of each week
  • Set realistic due dates based on weather and resource availability
  • Update task status promptly to track actual vs planned work
  • Review completed tasks to understand work patterns
  • Create tasks immediately when you notice something needs attention

Frequently Asked Questions#

How do I create a recurring task?

Currently, each task is created individually. For recurring activities, create a new task after completing the previous one, or plan multiple tasks in advance with different due dates.

item.title: Machines
item.description:
Machines Module#

Track your farm machinery including tractors and implements. Monitor usage patterns, maintenance schedules, and generate reports for service and usage history.

Key Features#

Tractors & Implements#

Machines are categorized into Tractors (powered equipment with engines) and Implements (attachments that connect to tractors).

Usage Tracking#

View usage histories for tractors. Track when and where each machine was used across your farm operations.

Expense Mapping#

Link tractors and implements to expenses on Farms, Fields, Crops, or Livestock. This helps analyze usage patterns and costs.

item.title: Notes
item.description:
Notes Action#

Record observations, comments, and important information about your farming activities.

Purpose#

Document anything noteworthy about your crops, animals, equipment, or fields. Notes serve as your farm diary, capturing observations, experiments, and lessons learned that help improve future decisions.

Key Features#

  • Free-form text - Write anything without structured fields
  • Date-stamped - Each note is automatically dated
  • Module linked - Notes are tied to specific crops, livestock, fields, etc.
  • Searchable - Find past notes by searching keywords
  • Historical record - Build a knowledge base over time

Available In#

Module Example Notes
Farm Weather events, visitor notes, annual plans, meeting summaries
Crops Pest sightings, growth observations, technique experiments
Fields Soil conditions, drainage issues, boundary markers
Livestock Behavior changes, health observations, breeding notes
Machines Unusual sounds, performance issues, repair history
Inventory Storage conditions, batch quality, supplier feedback

What to Record#

Crop Notes#

  • Pest or disease sightings with location and severity
  • Weather impact (heavy rain, frost, heatwave effects)
  • Growth observations (early flowering, stunted growth)
  • Experiment results (new fertilizer, different spacing)
  • Harvest quality observations

Livestock Notes#

  • Behavioral changes (reduced appetite, lethargy)
  • Health symptoms before calling the vet
  • Breeding observations (heat signs, mating dates)
  • Birth details (ease of delivery, offspring health)
  • Milk quality changes

Field Notes#

  • Soil conditions (waterlogging, erosion, compaction)
  • Drainage problems and solutions
  • Weed pressure areas
  • Pest hotspots for future reference
  • Successful crop combinations

Machine Notes#

  • Unusual sounds or vibrations
  • Performance issues
  • Repair details and parts used
  • Fuel consumption changes
  • Operator feedback

Tips#

  • Record weather observations that affect your farming
  • Document pest or disease sightings immediately with details
  • Note successful techniques for future reference
  • Include specific details: quantities, locations, severity
  • Write notes the same day - details fade quickly

Best Practices#

  • Be specific - “Aphids on lower leaves of row 3” is better than “pest problem”
  • Record immediately - Note observations the same day they occur
  • Use consistent terms - Makes searching easier later
  • Include context - Weather, recent activities, or anything relevant
  • Review periodically - Past notes often contain valuable lessons

Note Ideas by Season#

Pre-Season#

  • Soil preparation observations
  • Seed quality notes
  • Equipment readiness checks
  • Weather forecasts and plans

Growing Season#

  • Weekly growth observations
  • Pest and disease monitoring
  • Irrigation effectiveness
  • Fertilizer response

Harvest Season#

  • Yield quality observations
  • Timing notes (too early, just right, too late)
  • Labor and equipment performance
  • Market feedback on produce

Off-Season#

  • Lessons learned summary
  • Plans for next season
  • Equipment storage notes
  • Soil improvement observations

Frequently Asked Questions#

How is Notes different from Tasks?

Notes record observations and information (what happened, what you saw). Tasks schedule future activities (what needs to be done). Use Notes to document, use Tasks to plan.

item.title: Inventory
item.description:
Inventory Module#

Track your farm inventory including seeds, fertilizers, pesticides, fuel, spare parts, and more. Monitor stock levels, usage history, and link inventory items to expenses across all your farm operations.

Key Features#

Stock Management#

Track inventory levels with Add and Use transactions. Monitor current stock and closing balances for all items.

Category Organization#

Organize inventory by categories: Seeds, Fertilizers, Pesticides, Herbicides, Fuel, Spare Parts, Feed, Health products, and Yields.

item.title: Yields
item.description:
Yields Action#

Track harvest quantities and production output from your crops and livestock. Units are automatically set based on the module and production type.

Purpose#

Record crop harvests, milk production, egg collection, breeding outputs, and other measurable yields to monitor productivity and compare performance across seasons.

Key Features#

  • Automatic units - Units are set based on module and production type
  • Quality tracking - Record grades for premium vs regular produce
  • Production trends - Monitor yield patterns over time
  • Season comparison - Compare yields across different seasons
  • Individual animal yields - Track per-animal production for dairy cattle

Yield Units by Module#

Crop Yields#

All crop yields are measured in Kilograms (Kg).

item.title: Contacts
item.description:
Contacts Module#

Manage your farm contacts including vendors, buyers, laborers, and other business relationships. Track all transactions with each contact to see purchase and sale history in one place.

Key Features#

Contact Management#

Store and organize contacts for vendors, buyers, and other farm-related relationships.

Transaction Summary#

View all transactions with each contact including inventory purchases and crop/livestock sales.

Purchase Tracking#

When you buy inventory items and select a vendor, the purchase is automatically linked to that contact’s transaction history.

item.title: Documents
item.description:
Documents Action#

Attach files, photos, and documents to your farming records for visual tracking and record-keeping.

Purpose#

Store receipts, photos, certificates, manuals, and any other relevant files alongside your farming data. Documents provide visual evidence, backup records, and help track progress over time.

Key Features#

  • Photo attachments - Capture images directly or upload from gallery
  • File storage - Store PDFs, images, and other documents
  • Module linking - Documents are tied to specific crops, livestock, fields, etc.
  • Digital receipts - Keep purchase records without paper clutter
  • Progress tracking - Visual timeline of growth and changes

Available In#

Module Example Documents
Farm Land ownership papers, insurance policies, licenses, permits
Crops Growth photos, pest images, harvest pictures, seed labels
Fields Survey maps, soil test reports, land documents, aerial photos
Livestock Vaccination records, purchase receipts, pedigree certificates
Machines Service receipts, warranty cards, manuals, inspection reports
Inventory Purchase invoices, product labels, safety data sheets

Document Types to Store#

Legal & Ownership#

  • Land ownership documents
  • Lease agreements
  • Insurance policies
  • Government permits and licenses
  • Subsidy application copies

Financial Records#

  • Purchase receipts and invoices
  • Sale receipts
  • Bank statements
  • Loan documents
  • Tax records

Operational Records#

  • Soil test reports
  • Water quality reports
  • Veterinary prescriptions
  • Seed and fertilizer labels
  • Equipment manuals

Visual Documentation#

  • Crop growth progress photos
  • Pest and disease images
  • Harvest photos
  • Before/after comparison shots
  • Equipment condition photos

Photo Tips by Module#

Crop Photos#

  • Weekly progress - Same angle each week to show growth
  • Pest/disease - Close-up of affected areas with context shot
  • Harvest - Document yield quality and quantity
  • Problems - Capture issues immediately for expert consultation

Livestock Photos#

  • Health issues - Document symptoms before vet visit
  • Growth tracking - Periodic photos for development records
  • Newborns - Record births with date stamps
  • Injuries - Document for insurance or treatment records

Field Photos#

  • Aerial views - Overview of field conditions
  • Problem areas - Waterlogging, erosion, weed patches
  • Boundaries - Reference photos for disputes
  • Soil conditions - Before and after preparation

Machine Photos#

  • Condition records - Document state before/after repairs
  • Damage - For insurance claims
  • Meter readings - Hour meters, odometers for tracking

Tips#

  • Take photos of crop growth stages for visual progress tracking
  • Photograph receipts immediately before they fade or get lost
  • Store important documents like land papers and insurance policies
  • Use good lighting for clear, useful photos
  • Include context in photos (whole plant, not just close-up)

Best Practices#

  • Clear photos - Use good lighting, steady hand, focus on subject
  • Consistent angles - Same position for progress comparison
  • Immediate capture - Document issues as soon as you notice them
  • Descriptive names - Add notes about what the document shows
  • Regular backups - Ensure documents are synced to cloud
  • Organize by date - Makes finding documents easier

Frequently Asked Questions#

What file types can I upload?

You can upload images (JPG, PNG) and PDF documents. Photos can be taken directly within the app or selected from your gallery.

item.title: Animals
item.description:
Animals Action#

Manage individual animal profiles within your dairy cattle livestock for detailed per-animal tracking.

Purpose#

Track detailed information about each dairy animal including breed, health, breeding cycle, lineage, and milk production. This enables per-animal yield recording and helps identify top performers.

Availability#

Important: This action is only available when ALL conditions are met:

  • Module: Livestock
  • Animal Type: Cattle
  • Raised For: Dairy
  • Track Individually: ON

If you don’t see the Animals action, verify these settings in your livestock entry.

item.title: Roles & Team
item.description:
Roles Module#

Manage your farm team with different access levels. Assign roles to control what each team member can see and do in the app.

Key Features#

Role-Based Access#

Three user roles with different permission levels: Owner, Manager, and Worker.

Team Collaboration#

Add team members to your farm and assign appropriate roles based on their responsibilities.

Data Privacy#

Sensitive financial data like income is protected from worker access while allowing them to do their tasks.

item.title: Sitemap
item.description:
Sitemap#

Quick access to all documentation pages, modules, actions, and features.

Why Pannai?#

  • From Guessing to Knowing: A Farmer’s Journey - See how tracking transforms farming

Getting Started#

  • Getting Started Guide - Download, setup, and onboarding

Modules#

Core modules for managing your farm:

Module Description
Farm Farm profile, team management, farm-level activities
Crops Track crops from planting to harvest
↳ Seasons Organize crop activities by growth cycle
Fields Manage fields and crop rotation history
Livestock Cattle, poultry, goat, sheep, pig management
Machines Tractors, implements, usage and maintenance
Inventory Seeds, fertilizers, fuel, spare parts, yields
Contacts Vendors, buyers, transaction history
Roles Owner, Manager, Worker access levels

Actions#

Activities you perform on modules:

item.title: Farm
item.description:
Farm Module#

Create and manage your farm profile. The Farm module is the foundation of Pannai, where you set up your farm details and manage overall farm-level activities.

Key Features#

Farm Profile#

Set up your farm with essential details like name, location, and total area. This becomes your central hub for all farming activities.

Multi-Farm Support#

Manage multiple farms from a single account. Switch between farms to track activities for each property separately.
